title: 10-Day Mexico Culinary Journey
subtitle: Mexico City & Oaxaca: Street Food, Fine Dining & Ancient Flavors
meta_title: Mexico Food Tour Itinerary 2025 - 10 Days of Culinary Adventure
meta_description: The ultimate Mexico food itinerary: 10 days exploring Mexico City's markets and fine dining, Oaxacan moles and mezcal, cooking classes, and authentic regional cuisine.
hero_alt: Colorful Mexican street food spread with tacos and salsas
introduction: Mexican cuisine is UNESCO-recognized for good reason—it's one of the world's great culinary traditions, shaped by thousands of years of indigenous knowledge and global influences. This 10-day journey takes you deep into the food cultures of Mexico City and Oaxaca: from street tacos at dawn to tasting menus at world-ranked restaurants, from market foraging to cooking your own moles.
best_time: Year-round; October-November for Day of Dead culinary traditions
highlights: Dawn street food tour in Mexico City

days.title: Arrive Mexico City
days.description: Arrive in Mexico City and settle into your hotel in Roma or Condesa—the neighborhoods with the best food scene. Your introduction: a street food walking tour through Roma. Begin with proper tacos al pastor from a trompo (vertical spit), blue corn quesadillas filled with squash blossoms, and fresh fruit with chili and lime. End at a rooftop mezcal bar watching the city glow.
tips: Roma Norte has highest concentration of excellent restaurants
Street food is safe at busy stalls with high turnover
Mezcal: sip, don't shoot

days.title: Market Day & Fine Dining
days.description: Morning at Mercado de la Merced—one of the largest markets in the Americas. Your guide navigates the labyrinth of chilies, produce, meats, and prepared foods. Sample tamales, champurrado (thick chocolate drink), and whatever catches your eye. Afternoon rest, then tonight: dinner at Pujol, Quintonil, or Contramar—book months ahead. This is Mexico City's culinary pinnacle.
tips: Pujol requires reservations 2+ months ahead
Contramar is excellent and easier to book
Wear comfortable shoes for market—it's huge

days.title: Cooking Class & Coyoacán
days.description: Morning cooking class: learn to make salsas, street tacos, and perhaps mole. You'll shop at a local market for ingredients, then cook and feast on your creations. Afternoon in Coyoacán—the bohemian neighborhood where Frida Kahlo lived. Street food here includes tostadas, churros, and the famous Coyoacán market. Casual dinner in Coyoacán.
tips: Book cooking class in advance—popular ones fill up
Coyoacán market has excellent churros and tostadas
Try pulque if you're adventurous (fermented agave)

days.title: Taco Crawl & Lucha Libre
days.description: The legendary CDMX taco crawl. Your guide takes you to 4-5 taco spots specializing in different styles: tacos de canasta (basket tacos), tacos de guisado (stewed fillings), tacos de carnitas (slow-cooked pork), tacos árabes (Lebanese-influenced), and suadero (beef brisket). Evening: lucha libre wrestling at Arena México with beer and snacks—a cultural feast.
tips: Taco crawl: come hungry, wear stretchy pants
Lucha libre: Friday nights are most popular
El Huequito, Los Cocuyos, Taquería Orinoco are classics

days.title: Fly to Oaxaca
days.description: Morning flight to Oaxaca City—where Mexican food reaches its apotheosis. The UNESCO-recognized cuisine here includes seven moles, chapulines (grasshoppers), tlayudas (Oaxacan pizza), and the world's finest mezcal. Check into your hotel in the centro histórico, then afternoon walking food tour: chocolate atole, tlayudas, and your first proper Oaxacan mezcal tasting.
activities: Dinner at Zandunga or Los Danzantes
tips: Oaxacan mezcal is different from what you've had—taste carefully
Mayordomo and La Soledad for chocolate
Chapulines: try them—they're delicious

days.title: Seven Moles & Market Day
days.description: Oaxaca has seven famous moles, each with unique character: negro, rojo, coloradito, amarillo, verde, chichilo, and manchamanteles. Today you'll taste them all. Morning at Mercado 20 de Noviembre—the legendary food market with smoke-filled pasillos of grilled meats. Mole tasting lunch, then afternoon exploring Mercado Benito Juárez. Evening dinner at Origen or Pitiona.
activities: Fine dining at Origen or Pitiona
tips: Mole negro is the most complex—pay attention
Market breakfast: tasajo (dried beef), chorizo, cecina (thin-sliced pork)
Origen has excellent vegetarian mole options

days.title: Mezcal Route
days.description: Day trip into the mezcal-producing valleys. Visit a traditional palenque (distillery) where mezcal is made the ancestral way: roasting agave in underground pits, crushing with a horse-drawn tahona, fermenting in wood vats, distilling in clay pots. Taste mezcals you'll never find outside Oaxaca. Lunch at a village restaurant with fresh tortillas, return via Monte Albán.
tips: Don't buy mezcal before tasting at palenques—selection is better
Espadín is entry-level; try tobalá, madrecuixe, arroqueño
Mezcal education changes everything you know about the spirit

days.title: Oaxacan Cooking Class
days.description: The most important cooking class of your life. Morning market visit with your teacher—selecting dried chilies, fresh herbs, and specialty ingredients. Return to the kitchen to prepare a full Oaxacan meal: likely including salsa, mole (yes, from scratch—it takes hours), tamales, and mezcal cocktails. Eat your creations for a long, celebratory lunch.
tips: Casa de los Sabores and Seasons of My Heart are excellent cooking schools
Mole from scratch takes 4-6 hours—embrace the process
Take notes—you'll want to recreate this at home

days.title: Food Villages & Final Oaxaca
days.description: Visit the food villages surrounding Oaxaca. San Martín Tilcajete (alebrijes wood carvings), then San Bartolo Coyotepec (black pottery), and Tlacolula market if it's Sunday—the region's largest. Each village has food specialties. Return to Oaxaca for final dinner at your choice: street food feast at the zócalo, elevated Oaxacan at Criollo, or tasting menu at Casa Oaxaca.
tips: Tlacolula Sunday market is not to be missed if timing works
Buy mezcal and mole paste as gifts
In Situ mezcal bar has exceptional rare bottles

days.title: Departure
days.description: Final morning in food paradise. Early breakfast at your favorite market stall—one last tlayuda, one last atole. Pack your mezcal carefully (checked luggage only), your mole paste, your chocolate. Fly home with expanded palate, new cooking skills, and deep appreciation for one of the world's great culinary traditions.
tips: Mezcal must be in checked baggage—wrap well
Mole paste and chocolate travel well
Take restaurant business cards for future reference

practical_info.getting_there: Fly into Mexico City (MEX), fly out of Oaxaca (OAX) to Mexico City, then home. Direct flights from US to Oaxaca are rare—most connect through Mexico City or Houston.
practical_info.getting_around: Walking and Uber in Mexico City. Walking and taxis in Oaxaca. Arranged transport for day trips outside both cities.
what_to_pack: Notebook for recipes and restaurant names
Room in luggage for food souvenirs

faqs.question: Will I get sick from street food?
faqs.answer: Following basic precautions, most travelers are fine. Eat at busy stalls with high turnover. Avoid tap water and raw vegetables at questionable places. Street food in Mexico City and Oaxaca is generally safe—millions of locals eat it daily. Start slowly and trust your guide's recommendations.

faqs.question: Can this itinerary accommodate vegetarians?
faqs.answer: Yes, though you'll miss some signature dishes. Mexican cuisine has many vegetarian options: quesadillas with squash blossoms, tlayudas with beans and cheese, tamales with various fillings, and vegetarian moles. Let guides and restaurants know—they'll accommodate. Oaxacan fine dining has strong vegetarian offerings.

faqs.question: How do I get reservations at Pujol?
faqs.answer: Book online exactly 2 months before your desired date when reservations open. They release dates at a specific time—be ready. Alternatives if Pujol is booked: Quintonil (similar caliber), Contramar (excellent, easier), or Máximo Bistrot (neighborhood gem). All offer world-class Mexican cuisine.

faqs.question: How much mezcal can I bring home?
faqs.answer: US allows 5 liters per person duty-free. Beyond that, you pay taxes. Most mezcal from palenques comes in 750ml bottles, so you can bring ~6 bottles duty-free. Pack in checked luggage, well-wrapped. Consider shipping larger quantities through specialty importers.
